p: Bacille Calmette–Guérin (BCG), the current vaccine against TB, has important protective effects against other infections. In randomised trials, BCG reduced infant mortality by around 40% [ 49] and respiratory infections other than TB by 70% in adolescents [ 50]. These “nonspecific effects” of BCG vaccination are explained by epigenetic and metabolic reprogramming of innate immune cells, a process termed “trained immunity” [ 51]. Clinical evidence suggests that BCG may protect against viruses [ 52], and BCG-vaccinated healthy adults re-challenged with live yellow fever vaccine showed improved antiviral immunity and decreased viral loads [ 53]. In mice, BCG vaccination protects against influenza A, lowering viral replication and lung injury [ 54, 55].
